Package wt.preference

The Preference Package

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    MultiValuedPreferenceHandler
    PreferenceValueHandler extension to support MultiValuedPreferenceInstance object.
    PreferenceService2
    Interface specifying methods needed to provide client accessible server-side functionality for managing preferences.
    PreferenceValueHandler
    Interface specifying behavior needed for processing the preference values.

    Class Description

    AbstractPreference


    Supported API: true

    Extendable: false
    LoadPreference
    Creates and persists preference objects based on input from a comma seperated value (csv) file.

    MultiValuedPreferenceInstance is a holder for multiple vales for a PreferenceInstance.
    PreferenceCategory
    The PreferenceCategory is an object used for grouping preferences to together.

    Supported API: true

    Extendable: false

    The PreferenceClient is an object used to represent the various clients that could be using preferences (e.g.
    PreferenceDefinition
    The PreferenceDefinition is the object that contains all of the static information about a preference.
    PreferenceHelper
    Provides access to the PreferenceService2 Application Programming Interface (API) via the static reference PreferenceHelper.service and several helper methods.
    PreferenceInstance
    The PreferenceInstance object is the "instantiation" of a PreferenceDefinition, its main task is to store a user defined value of the preference.

Package wt.preference Description

The Preference Package

 

Table of Contents

1.     Introduction

2.     The Preference Object Model

3.     Preference Instance Precedence

4.     Using Preferences

5.     Customization Intent

6.     Other Important Information

 

Introduction

 

What is the purpose of this documentation?

The purpose of this documentation is to give an overview of the package and its key classes and to give the developer the basic tools needed to create and use a preference.

 

What is the purpose of the Preference Package?

The purpose of this package is to provide a mechanism to allow developers to write software with aspects that are configurable by customers.  A �preference� is a single aspect that is configurable.  For instance, in the GUI there a strings that are truncated if they are longer than a certain length; that truncation length is a good candidate for a preference.  Using the preference package this aspect could be mage configurable. 

 

The Preference Object Model

           

What are Preference Definitions?

The PreferenceDefinition is the object that contains all of the static information about a preference such as:

�        Internal Name - Each preference is identified by a unique internal name. (This is equivalent to the fully qualified preference name in the old preference package which consisted of 3 elements: root node, parent node and key. The internal names of preferences carried forward from the old scheme are constructed simply as: rootnode + �/� + parentnode + �/� + key).

�        Default Value - The default value of the preference (used if there are no applicable PreferenceInstances).

�        Display Name - This is the localized name of the preference that the user will see in the GUI.

�        Display Short Description - This is the localized short description of the preference that the user will see in the GUI.

�        Display Long Description - This is the localized full description of the preference that the user will see in the GUI.

�        Visibility - This indicates in which parts of the Preference Manager GUI the preference will be visible:

o       Hidden - Invisible to the GUI.  Should there be a need to set these preferences there is a command-line utility wt.preference.SetPreferenceUtility.

o       Site - Only visible in the Site Utilities Preference Manager.

o       Org - Visible in all Organization and the Site Utilities Preference Managers.

o       Container - Visible in all Container, all Organization and the Site Utilities Preference Managers.

o       User - Visible in all Home (User), all Container, all Organization and the Site Utilities Preference Managers.

o       User Only - Only visible in all Home (User) Utilities Preference Managers.

�        Preference Value Handler - The handler for processing the preference values. The handler defines the type of preference (e.g. Boolean, String, Pick from a list).  The handler interface was designed, so that a type of preference is not limited to only a few select types. The handler interface allows for the specification of how a preference value is edited, stored and displayed.

 

What are Preference Clients?

The PreferenceClient is an object used to represent the various clients that could be using preferences (e.g. Windchill, Pro/E, AutoCAD). A link between a client and a definition indicates that the preference is used by the client.  Instances can be defined against a specific client.  Not all preferences are relevant to all clients.  Clients exist in a hierarchical structure, with Windchill being the default or root client, for example:

As you will see, most of the APIs for getting or setting a preference value take a client internal name which identifies the object in the database. One may ask, �How do I know what internal name to use?�  Well, the concept of a PreferenceClient was introduced for the most part to satisfy Unified Work Group Managers (UWGM) requirements so, if you don�t know what internal name to use chances are you don�t care about clients and should just use the default client internal name: WINDCHILL.  There is even a nice static variable PreferenceClient.WINDCHILL_CLIENT_NAME that you should use. 

 

What are Preference Client Definitions?

The PreferenceClientDefinition is a link object linking a PreferenceDefinition and a PreferenceClient.  Such a link must exist in order for a value of the preference to be set for the client.  From the definition side it can be navigated to get the clients at which the preference can be set and from the client side it can be navigated to get all the definition that can be set against that client.  Also, for a preference to appear in the GUI at the least a link must exist between the PreferenceDefinition and the default (WINDCHILL) PreferenceClient. 

 

What are Preference Instances?

The PreferenceInstance object is the �instantiation� of a definition, its main task is to store a user defined value of the preference.  An instance is created when a value for a preference is set.  Setting a value of a preference definition is creating (or modifying) an instance.  An instance contains a value of the preference for a specific client/context pair.  The client types are explained above.

Here are the context types:

�        Site

�        Organization

�        Container (Project, Product, or Library)

�        User

The context stored in an instance always a specific rather than a general context.  Meaning I can set a value against a specific container and not against �containers� in general.

When getting the value of a preference the instance most specific to the retrieval context is generally used, however instances can be locked as well and a locked instance will override instances at lower contexts and clients.  See section on Preference Instance Precedence for more details.

 

What are Preference Client Instances?

The PreferenceClientInstance is a link object linking a PreferenceInstance and a PreferenceClient.  Such a link is created when an instance is created.  From the instance side it can be navigated to get the client at which the instance is set and from the client side it can be navigated to get all the instances set against that client.

 

What are Preference Value Handlers?

The PreferenceValueHandler object (not in the above model) is used for processing the preference values.  Each preference definition has one and it contains all the logic specifying:

�        How to store the value

�        How to edit/process the value in the �Edit Preference� wizard.

�        How to validate the inputted values

�        How to display the value in the �Preference Manager�

 

There are various predefined handlers to meet most data-type needs:

�        Boolean

�        String

�        Choice (from a list)

�        Number

�        Et cetera (see subclasses of PreferenceValueHandler for full list)

 

It is possible to create your own by implementing the PreferenceValueHandler interface.

 

What are Preference Categories?

The PreferenceCategory is an object used for grouping preferences to together.  A category may also have subcategories or be the child of another category.  Every preference definition has a category but they are not part of the identity of a preference, rather, categories are a way to organize the preferences within the GUI.  If a category is defined but has no definitions associated to it the category will not show up in the GUI.

 

Preference Instance Precedence

The chief logic involved in this package is determining what instance applies in which context and client for a particular preference.  The algorithm is somewhat complex. What I describe here is not exactly how it is implemented but the results are the same.

The inputs to the algorithm are a preference definition, a context and a client.  The definition is used to retrieve all instances of the definition.   The context passed in is used to further refine the considered instances:

�        If the site context is passed in only the instances of site will be considered

�        If an organization context is passed in only the instances of that organization and site instances will be considered

�        If a container context is passed only the instances of that container, the organization of the container and site will be considered

�        If a user context is passed in only the instances of that user, the container the user is working in (if applicable), the organization of the container and site will be considered

The client passed in is also used to filter the instances: only instances of the client or its ancestor clients are considered.  The retained instances are then divided into groups by client.  The next step is compare instances by context, so we�ll call this step �Context Compare�.  For each of these client groups the highest precedence instance is chosen based on context and the existence of any locks.  The following diagram demonstrates the precedence:

So a locked site instance has highest precedence and the site instance has the lowest (default value is not an instance). For example if a user instance and an org instance both exist the user instance will take precedence.  After a single instance is selected from each client group then these instances are compared.  We�ll call this step �Client Compare�.  If there are no locked instances the instance of the most specific client will take precedence (i.e. the instance of the client passed in to the algorithm will be chosen if one exists).  However a locked instance at a higher context and client take precedence.  So for example, if the client passed in was �Child Client� and the chosen instance for that client was a user instance and the chosen instance for its parent client �Windchill� was a locked container instance the instance chosen would be the locked container instance.  However if the chosen instance for the �Child Client� was a container instance the container instance would take precedence.  If no instances exist then the default value will be used.

So the algorithm looks something like this:

The important, higher-level steps to the algorithm are:

1.      Collect applicable instances based on preference definition, context and client.

2.      �Context Compare� - divide instances from step 1 into groups by client and select highest context precedence instance from each group.

3.      �Client Compare� - compare instances selected in step 2 by client and lock status, select highest precedence instance to use.

 

Using Preferences

So far we have explained how preferences work internally.  Now we will explain how they can be used, which is what you probably wanted to know in the first place.

 

How do I define and create a preference?

To create a preference you have to use the data-load framework.  Preferences are loaded from load-files.  The load-files follow the following naming convention: preference.solution.xml

The installed.properties will be used to identify what solutions preferences need to be loaded.  The loader is designed to be used to handle updates as well as initial loads.  The files can be loaded from the command-line, for example:

 

windchill wt.load.LoadFromFile -u wcadmin -p wcadmin -d %WT_HOME%/loadFiles/preference.foundation.xml

 

A new preference should be added to the most applicable load-file.  So, for instance, do not put a ProjectLink specific preference in preference.foundation.xml, but rather in preference.projectlink.xml

 

There are xml tags for creating the main objects in the model:

�        csvPreferenceCategory - for loading a PreferenceCategory

�        csvPreferenceDefinition - for loading a PreferenceDefinition

�        csvPreferenceClient - for loading a PreferenceClient

�        csvLinkPreferenceClientDefinition - for loading a PreferenceClientDefinition

�        csvPreferenceInstance - for loading a PreferenceInstance

 

and there are xml tags for deleting those objects:

�        csvDeletePreferenceCategory

�        csvDeletePreferenceDefinition

�        csvDeletePreferenceClient

�        csvUnlinkPreferenceClientDefinition

�        csvDeletePreferenceInstance

 

Here are some example usages (by no means exhaustive):

�        Creating a category

<csvPreferenceCategory handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceCategory">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_CATEGORY</csvname>

    <csvparentName></csvparentName>

    <csvdisplayName>wt.example.exampleResource:EXAMPLE_CATEGORY_DISP_NAME</csvdisplayName>

    <csvdescription></csvdescription>

</csvPreferenceCategory>

 

�        Creating a definition

<csvPreferenceDefinition handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceDefinition">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_PREFERENCE</csvname>

    <csvvisibility>USER</csvvisibility>

    <csvcategoryName> EXAMPLE_CATEGORY </csvcategoryName>

    <csvdisplayName>wt.example.exampleResource:EXAMPLE_ PREFERENCE _DISP_NAME</csvdisplayName>

    <csvdescription>wt.example.exampleResource:EXAMPLE_ PREFERENCE _SHORT_DESC</csvdescription>

    <csvlongDescription>wt.example.exampleResource:EXAMPLE_ PREFERENCE _LONG_DESC</csvlongDescription>

    <csvdefaultValue>example default string</csvdefaultValue>

    <csvhandler>com.ptc.windchill.enterprise.preference.handler.StringPreferenceValueHandler:initialization string</csvhandler>

</csvPreferenceDefinition>

 

�        Creating a client

<csvPreferenceClient handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceClient">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvname>

    <csvparentName></csvparentName>

    <csvdisplayName>wt.example.exampleResource:EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvdisplayName>

    <csvdescription></csvdescription>

</csvPreferenceClient>

 

�        Creating a link between a client and a definition

<csvLinkPreferenceClientDefinition handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.setClientDefinitionLink">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_PREFERENCE</csvname>

    <csvclientName>EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvclientName>

</csvLinkPreferenceClientDefinition>


 

�        Creating an instance at the Site level

<csvPreferenceInstance handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceInstance">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_PREFERENCE</csvname>

    <csvclientName>EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvclientName>

    <csvvalue>example non-default string</csvvalue>

    <csvlock>true</csvlock>

</csvPreferenceInstance>

 

�        Creating an instance at an Organization level

<csvPreferenceInstance handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceInstance">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_PREFERENCE</csvname>

    <csvorganization>ExampleOrgName<csvorganization>

    <csvclientName>EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvclientName>

    <csvvalue>example non-default string</csvvalue>

    <csvlock>true</csvlock>

</csvPreferenceInstance>

 

�        Creating an instance at a Container level

<csvPreferenceInstance handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceInstance">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_PREFERENCE</csvname>

    <csvcontainerClass>wt.pdmlink.PDMLinkProduct</csvcontainerClass>

    <csvcontainerName>ExampleContainerName</csvcontainerName>

    <csvparentContainerPath>/wt.inf.container.OrgContainer=ExampleOrgName</csvparentContainerPath>

    <csvclientName>EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvclientName>

    <csvvalue>example non-default string</csvvalue>

    <csvlock>true</csvlock>

</csvPreferenceInstance>

 

�        Creating an instance at a User level

<csvPreferenceInstance handler="wt.preference.LoadPreference.createPreferenceInstance">

    <csvname>EXAMPLE_PREFERENCE</csvname>

    <csvuser>ExampleUserName</csvuser>

    <csvclientName>EXAMPLE_CLIENT</csvclientName>

    <csvvalue>example non-default string</csvvalue>

    <csvlock>true</csvlock>

</csvPreferenceInstance>

 

The delete tags are very similar and are used rarely so they will not be covered here.

Once you have created a preference through the load files you can then start getting and setting its value.

 

What are the APIs for getting a preference value?

For getting the value of a single preference use PreferenceService�s �getValue()� APIs, for example:

 

String definitionName = �EXAMPLE_DEFINITION�;

String clientName = �EXAMPLE_CLIENT�;

WTContainerRef containerRef = �;

WTUser user = �;

 

Object preferenceValue = PreferenceHelper.service.getValue(containerRef, definitionName, clientName, user);

 

For getting the value of a multiple preferences use PreferenceService�s �getValues()� APIs, for example:

 

ArrayList<String> definitionNames = new ArrayList<String>();

definitionNames.add("PREFERENCE_DEFINITION_1");

definitionNames.add("PREFERENCE_DEFINITION_2");

definitionNames.add("PREFERENCE_DEFINITION_3");

definitionNames.add("PREFERENCE_DEFINITION_4");

String clientName = �EXAMPLE_CLIENT�;

WTContainerRef containerRef = �;

WTUser user = �;

 

Map<String,Object> preferenceMap = PreferenceHelper.service.getValues(containerRef, definitionNames, null, clientName, user);

 

Both these methods are overloaded with arguments suiting various context needs.  Remember from the section on the instance precedence that the client and context you pass in are important pieces in determining which instance is used to get the value that is returned by these APIs, so be sure that if you want to get the value of the preference for a certain client and context that you pass in that client and context.  There have been many cases of people thinking that preference service was broken when in reality they were using the wrong version of the API or passing the wrong arguments for their needs. For instance, if a Preference Definition has defined its visibility to be USER, then the appropriate getValue() API to call for retrieving values of this preference should take both the WTUser object and WTContainerRef object (if the preference is being retrieved in an applicable container context). This is because the USER visibility allows for a preference value to be set at all the available contexts, and it may be locked in the container in which the user is operating or at a higher level.

 

What are the API�s for setting a preference value?

For setting the value of a single preference use PreferenceService�s �setValue()� APIs, for example:

 

Object preferenceValue = PreferenceHelper.service.setValue(definitionName, clientName, value, locked, container)

 

This method is overloaded with arguments suiting various context needs.  Again, remember to be sure that if you want to set the value of the preference for a certain client and context that you pass in that client and context. 

 

There has been no need as of yet for a multi-object API for setting preferences.

 

Customization Intent

 

In what ways are preferences customizable?

The answer is very few.  Unless you own this code the only thing you should be doing is defining preferences in load files and writing concrete implementations of PreferenceValueHandler if an existing handler does not exist to suit your needs.

 

Other Important Information

 

What are some limitations of the Preference Package?

�        There is no way to create a preference with visibility that is specific to a certain organization, container or user.  For example, if you create a container visibility preference it will be visible in the preference manager for all containers, if you create a user level preference it will be visible in the preference manager for all users.

�        There is no way to create a preference that is specific to a container type (e.g., a preference that is only for a project container)

�        The creation of preferences is strictly done through the load-file mechanism. There is currently no support in the GUI to create Preference Definitions.

 

What are some other capabilities of the Preference Package?

�        It is possible to hide a preference on data-load based on what solutions are installed.

�        In the edit preference GUI it is possible to have a dropdown containing clients to set a preference value against. A current limitation is that this list must contain all the clients and does not allow specifying just a subset.
